Node.transition: Anatomically the ear is divided into 3 parts:

Item.id: Is made of elastic cartilage with skin around it.
Its function is to direct sound towards the ear.
Is attached to the skull via muscles ligaments.

Node.id: The anatomical parts of the auricle are:

equalize the pressure in the tympanic cavity with the atmospheric pressure" alignment="1" arrowcolor="-65536" arrowsize="1" backgroundcolor="-1" foregroundcolor="-16777216" initialexpanded="0" linecolor="-16776961" linesize="1" fontsize="1">

Item.id: Medially with lateral wall of the inner ear.
Is the largest of the 3 bones.
Head of malleus articulates with the incus.
Manubrium of malleus is attached to the tympanic membrane.
Tensor tympani muscle attaches to the manubrium.
Articulates with malleus stapes.
Head of stapes articulates with incus.
Base of stapes articulates with oval window via annular ligament.
Stapedius muscle attaches to head of stapes.
Is a series of bony canals within the petrous part of temporal bone.
Is lined with periosteum.
Is separated from membranous labyrinth by a fluid called the perilymph.
Contains the membraneous labyrinth.
Funcation: balance
Lies in 3 planes of space: posterior, lateral, anterior

<Item id="Is medial to tympanic membrane, anterior to cochlea, posterior to
semici" alignment="1" arrowcolor="-65536" arrowsize="1" backgroundcolor="-1" foregroundcolor="-16777216" initialexpanded="0" linecolor="-16776961" linesize="1" fontsize="1"> <Item id="Anteriorly opens to scala vestibuli of cohclea, posteriorly opens to
ampullae of semici" alignment="1" arrowcolor="-65536" arrowsize="1" backgroundcolor="-1" foregroundcolor="-16777216" initialexpanded="0" linecolor="-16776961" linesize="1" fontsize="1">

Item.id: Contains perilymph
Contains endolymph
Contains perilymph.
Ends at the round window.
Is a series of sacs tubes inside the bony labyrinth.
Floats in perilymph.

Item.id:
Fuel for the Knowledge Economy ™
Overview Global Edutainment, Inc
is a company in Los Angeles, California with a unique portfolio of intellectual properties geared towards transforming the learning and teaching process into an enjoyable experience
Most significantly, the company has developed a “visual language”-- TheBigPicture (TBP) language
The Big Picture language is a breakthrough in human communication with the potential to produce a major cultural revolution comparable to Gutenberg’s invention of movable type
There are numerous applications and usages for TBP language in diverse market segments, with potential to spin off new industries
Perhaps the most significant initial application will be its role in helping the millions of individuals suffering from learning disabilities and Attention Deficit Syndrome (ADS)
According to the International Dyslexia Association, 15-20% of the population has a reading disability
Billions of dollars are spent every year by government, business, researchers, and private individuals to combat dyslexia and other pervasive learning disabilities
The Company promises to solve the bulk of this difficult puzzle
In short, text expressed in TBP language empowers readers to easily digest the content of a document- even for many who have been diagnosed with “learning disabilities”
TBP language is comprised of many pedagogical tools (e

graphic organizers, semantic maps) that have been subject to stringent research and have long been found by cognitive psychologists and many educators to improve comprehension and memory for both challenged and non-challenged readers
Despite the research supporting the effectiveness of graphic representation of text, the implementation has not been without problems
Development of such materials tax the time of already overburdened teachers
In addition, many teachers lack the training and experience to employ such techniques
Even if publishers were willing to broadly include such formats in future publications, it would do little for the myriad of texts already published
To solve the implementation challenge of presenting text visually, numerous research companies with advanced knowledge of software technologies have been working to provide the answers
As a result, a new field has emerged called “Information Visualization”
However, for the most part, the research findings remain in the labs of universities and corporate research centers around the world
A visual language is considerably more complex than semantic maps
That is, a visual language allows for complete presentation of a topic graphically without dependence of its linear text counterpart
Is it possible for someone to read entire textbook in sciences, mathematics, history, arts, or business in a visual language? As such, the companyGlobal Edutainment, Inc
is the first company in the world to have succeeded in developing a visual language with potential for wide spread adoption in diverse disciplines and market segments
TBP language has been successfully applied to thousands of pages of information including academic and general topics
, Iinformally tested and used by over 10,000 learners, and it has also undergone refinementsignificantly evolved over the past two decades since its inception
Most practically, Global Edutainment, Inc

has developed software innovativeprocesses (6 pending patents with the first one approved) to semi-automate authoring topics in TBP language, as well as enabling anyone to processes to rapidly mass convert large quantities of existing information in their possession into TBP language easily and cost effectively

The company has successfully developed tFor example, the prototype of its software which can demonstrate the semi-automated conversion of an entire text of a science or history textbook, a training manual, a VCR manual, or even a newspaper into TBP language
The Business: The Company’s Company’s mission is to build a global service company that offers an online and offline access to TBP tools for producing content in TBP lLanguage

Publishing companies may license the authoring and conversion tools to mass-produce textbooks in TBP lLanguage with various delivery options including the internet, CDs, DVD, s, hand-held devices, e-books, and print media
Businesses may license the tools to convert training manuals, product and service literature into TBP language in order to make their content more accessible for those with reading disabilities
Government agencies may use TBP technologies to make their vast resources of public information more accessible for diverse learners
Educators and researchers may use TBP tools to produce lectures and curriculum in a visual language
Global The CompanyEdutainment, Inc
has gathered a mastermind group of experienced professionals on its Advisory Board
This mastermind includes business executives, technology experts, educators, scientists, researchers, and other creative talentsindividuals
With strong support from the educational community, several investors, including Mr
Joseph Duncan, former Senior Vice President of Oracle Corporation provided the seed funding for prototype development

Other high profileprominent individuals on the company’s Advisory Board include:
· Dr
Kirstie Bellman, former Program Manager for the Department of Defense (DARPA 93-97), developed and managed the largest government funded education technology program in the U
with $100 M-plus budget) · Dr
Jim Spohrer, CTO, IBM Venture Capital Relations Group · Mr

Richard Saul Wurman, Chairman of TED conferences
The company is now seeking a $5 mMillion of investment from visionary individuals and corporations to complete software development, establish partnership agreement with key partners, develop topics in TBP lLanguage for different market segments as case scenarios, and launch TBP authoring and conversion services
Vision Our vision is to transform the educational system across the worldglobally by: 1
Developing TBP tools that make learning and teaching easy; 2
Setting the international standard in visual and interactive communication; 3
Fueling the economy and creating jobs for information architects and knowledge workers
Within the next ten years we will see substantial shifts in how and where people work
The labor force will eventually shift away from the production and provision of physical goods and services to information technologies and services
Information specialists and architects of the information economy will perform these jobs
TBP technologies may be foundational to such a shift in the labor market
Just as manufacturing tools fueled the industrial economy, providing tools that will empower people to communicate information efficiently and effectively will drive the Information Economy
History Dr
Ray Emrani, Executive VP & CTO: The Big Picture was born in the imagination of Ray Emrani in 1979

As a young student in Manchester, England, Ray began to experiment with ways of deconstructing linear information and re-representing the information as visual, linked diagrams in order to see how the parts related to the whole

Later in America, for the next two decades he embarked upon a comprehensive program of independent research into education, cognition, memory, information architecture, visualization, brain structure and function, learning disabilities, psychology, interactive multimedia, Graphical User Interface, and software design

His passion to identify and find practical solutions to various difficulties encountered during the learning process resulted in a sweeping vision that has now been formally organized into The Big Picture Project
Dr
Emrani holds 6 pending patents on new methods of expressing information, collaborating, and publishing paradigms
James J
Showghy, President & CEO: In 1995, Dr
James Showghy joined The Big Picture project as President & CEO of Global Edutainment, Inc
to provide the next level of investment capital needed to complete the R&D and provide business development guidance for Global Edutainment, Inc
Dr
Showghy has a long track record of successful business venture development and investment strategies
In 1984, as President & CEO of Beverly Hills Multispeciality Medical Group, Inc
, he developed an extremely successful chain of medical clinics from ground zero
By 1994 whenthe time he liquidated the business in 1994, the clinics had grossed over $100 million
Prior to his business ventures, Dr
Showghy was a full-time professor of Clinical Psychiatry at UCLA with special interests in education and teaching

Summary of Milestones:
1979-1995: Research & Development · Dr
Ray Emrani conceives of the idea of presenting knowledge visually as a young student in Manchester, England in 1979
· “TheBigPicture” Visual Language invented and refined in U
· Ray converts thousands of pages of information in diverse topics into TBP language successfully completed on large drawing papers- manually
· Over 10,000 students use TBP l Language in a variety of private, group, and classroom tutoring environments
· Endorsements from researchers and educators

· Numerous academic textbook publishers including McGraw-Hills and Churchill Livingston praise TBP language but find it impractical to produce study guides using TBP language due to size and cost of production
1995-2000: Research & Development continues to overcome the cost structures: · Dr
James Showghy joins TheBigPicture project as President & CEO and investing $250 K over the next 5 years
· Expanded endorsements from researchers and educators
· Software processes for authoring text in TBP Language invented
· Software processes for converting existing text to TBP language invented
· A portfolio of related intellectual properties invented
· 4 Patents filed on the invented processes
· Formation of Advisory Board (see “Advisory Board” document for member profiles)
2001-2002: Prototype completed · Seed funding received total of $400 K from: - Mr
Joseph Duncan, former Senior VP of Oracle - Ms
Marcie Polier, Founder of Entertainment Data, Inc
- Mr
William Shernoff, Esq
of Shernoff, Bidart & Darras Law · 1st patent is approved by the United States Department of Commerce- this invention explains how any text can be converted semi-automatically into graphical format
· Increased network to individuals for business development
· 2 additional patents filed (total of 6 pending patents with the first one approved)
· Prototype of the tool for easy and rapid communication of TBP visual language development successfully completed
for the first tool for easy and rapid communication of a visual language in the world · IBM and Global Edutainment sign mutual NDA
IBM commits to developing cost structure for online hosting of TBP application
Expected completion of cost model by January 20, 2002
Agreement with IBM to host TBP service as an ISP provider in progress
· Cisco and Global Edutainment sign mutual NDA and commit to pilot project converting samples of Cisco technical documentation to TBP language
Discussions with Cisco about business relationship with Global Edutainment to commence upon successful completion of pilot conversion project

The Opportunity / Size of the Market: Current technologies have facilitated the Internet revolution without fundamentally transforming the ways that information is presented so as to have a significant impact on the way most people learn-- visually

The fundamental opportunity for the future of publishing and online communication resides in defining the standards that take full advantage of the attributes of interactive digital media to facilitate learning and communication
According to Credit Suisse/First Boston: Equity Research
· More money is spent in the United States on education than in any other industry with the exception of health care
Annual expenditures are more than social security and defense combined
· In 1998, education was the primary full-time occupation (including students) of approximately 75 million people in the United States, representing over 1 in 4 people
· Public schools in the United States (grades K-12) spent $2
9 billion on instructional technology in 1998
This amount is projected to increase to $6
8 billion by 2003
· In 1998, approximately 700,000 students were enrolled in distance learning courses and this number is projected to increase to over 2
2 million by 2002
· The corporate e-Learning market in 1997 was $234 million but is expected to increase to $11
4 billion by 2003

Value proposition:
Benefits to publishers and corporate training developers: · Extends the life cycle of current assets by transforming content into new format that more individuals can access (especially the learning disabled population)
· Competitive advantage and enhanced branding over publishers who do not provide a visual language of their text
· Broadens global market opportunities due to its adaptability to different languages ? Benefits to educators: · Can easily be easily integrated into existing curricula
· Great Highly effective tool for classroom teaching- teachers can provide the “big picture” while exploring the details, allowing students to easily follow the lecture
Benefits to businesses selling products or services with complex literatures: · Companies producing products such as VCRs, dDigital vVideo cCameras, hHand held devices, cell phones, etc
may communicate their product features and usage in an easy format to novice customers
· Companies providing services such as investment, retirement, medical or legal information to lay individuals will be able to express those information more effectively
· Competitive advantage and enhanced branding over companies who do not provide their products or services in a visual language format
TBP TECHNOLOGY REPRESENTS A POTENTIAL “KILLER APP” WITH APPLICATIONS TO DIVERSE MARKET SEGMENTS

Revenue sources: Revenue sources include:
1
Royalties from content produced in TBP language: Revenue-sharing model will be implemented with publishers and other content providers
Subscription to TBP authoring and conversion tools: Software rental model will be implemented with non-commercial publishers
For example, corporate training or business communicators may subscribe to the tools for internal sharing of documents in TBP language
Technical support: Additional recurring revenue per month would be available for back office technical support to answer technical questions from customers
Hosted Services: Hosted services are based on subscription dollars per user per month
Competitive Landscape: From software development companies: Information visualization technology is emerging from research into practice
Numerous research centers and companies all over the world are working to develop new publishing paradigms based on new ways of interacting with information
The Company believes that its technology is 10-20 years ahead of its competitors based on field research and publications
Competition is therefore likely to come from imitators and not from other proactive companies
From content publishers: Based on our field research, there are no publishers who have the technology to publish material that can offer the significant benefits gained from content in TBP lLanguage
